title: Rutting bucks try to prove who's toughest as they lock antlers in London park brawl
text:
Advertisement

Three fallow deer bucks were pictured battling it out in a London park on Sunday while trying to prove who's toughest of the herd.

The male deer locked antlers in a brutal fight in Bushy Park in Richmond, west London.

Amanda Cook, 50, spotted the deer 'rutting in Bushy Park' and took the chance to photograph the brawl.

Amanda Cook spotted the three male fallow deer (pictured) locking antlers in a brutal fight in Bushy Park in Richmond, west London

Ms Cook said: 'To be honest I have never seen three fighting together. They certainly were going for it!!'

It is not known what riled the three bucks at the weekend.

However, bucks typically resort to fighting when competing for either territory or for the attentions of a female deer.

During autumn, deer rutting takes place, with male deer roaring, barking and clashing antlers to try to lure in as many females as possible to mate with.

Bushy Park has been a popular stomping ground for deer, since it was turned into a deer chase by Henry VIII. The three rutting bucks (pictured) on Sunday are thought to be fighting over either territory or female attention

Bushy Park is a popular stomping ground for deer, with both red and fallow deer known to roam freely throughout the park.

The Royal Park was turned into a deer chase by Henry VIII, with hunting being a favourite past-time of his.

Today the park boasts around 320 deer and claims their grazing is crucial to maintaining wildlife in the area.

Though few would want to get on the wrong side of them, herds are kept out of certain areas of the park, including the Woodland Gardens and other protected plantations.
description: Three fallow deer bucks were pictured battling it out in a London Park on Sunday trying to prove who's toughest of the herd. The male deer locked antlers in a brutal fight in Bushy Park, London.
